name: cement production, CP II-F | cement, CP II-F | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20501/documentation

The dataset describes the production of blended Portland cement production with the addition of milled limestone as filler. There are three types of blended cement in Brazil (CP II) depending on the supplementary cementitious materials (SCM): slag (E), pozzolan (Z) and limestone filler (F). CP II-F has between 6% to 10% of limestone filler in mass composition. The three Blended cement types are specified by Brazilian standards (ABNT NBR 11578:1991).;Six types of Portland and blended cement types represent Brazilian production. The table below presents the different cement types and compositions according to Brazilian standards (NBR 11578:1991, NBR 5735:1991, NBR 5736:1991, NBR 5733:1991).;The CP II cement types are the most consumed cement in Brazil. CP II represents 62.1% of the market according to the National Union of the Cement Industry (SNIC, 2013). Its applications range from reinforced and ordinary concrete to coating mortars. This cement provides to concrete a lower hydration heat than ordinary Portland Cement. In addition, it also improves capillarity and permeability of mortar and concrete due to the grain size of the milled limestone. The CP II-F cement consists of clinker, calcium sulfate, and milled limestone (see composition in the table).;This dataset contains information from clinker stockpile to cement ready to be shipped in bulk. After the clinker is cooled from the rotary kiln, it is ground in ball or roller mills to particles under 75 μm size. Then it goes to silos where it is mixed with calcium sulphate (gypsum) and SCMs. The mixed cement goes to a finishing mill and then it is stored in cement silos, ready to be shipped in bulk or packed.;Primary data were gathered from six cement manufacturers in Brazil, who informed the total values of inputs and outputs related to cement production in 2016, considering all their cement production sites. All types of flows were reported, namely: primary and secondary raw materials and fuels, auxiliary materials, electricity and water consumption. It corresponds to 70% market share, considered a good representativeness level. Although particulate emissions may occur, they are not reported due to lack of specific data for the cement grinding step (air emissions are monitored for the integrated clinker-cement plant as a whole and reported in the clinker production process).

The activity starts with the reception of raw materials in the cement plant. In plants which are integrated with clinker production, clinker is stored in the silo after cooling in the upstream process (clinker production /BR).

The activity includes the drying of raw materials, the grinding and mixing of raw materials for cement production in the cement mill (with grinding aids) and ends with cement stored in silos, ready to be shipped. Waste or particulate emission are not considered due to the lack of data. The dataset does not include packaging and administration.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2394:Manufacture of cement, lime and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period corresponds to data collection period (2016).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents production of cement blended with limestone 6-10% for Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Current technology for cement production in Brazil.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data represent 70% of Brazilian cement production. This sample is extrapolated to represent the production in the whole country. The main values are considered representative for a typical production of Portland cement blended with limestone in Brazil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data represent circa 70% of the Brazilian cement production in 2016, which is considered a good representativeness level. Data were provided by six cement manufacturers, via confidential questionnaires, regarding the production of cement during the year of 2016. Raw materials flows are the weighted average of the cement composition informed by each cement manufacturer. The weighing factor used is the total cement production volume, since manufacturers did not report the production volumes of each cement type due to confidentiality. Basic uncertainty was calculated based on the sample"s weighted standard deviation and represents variation of composition between manufacturers/factories. For other input flows (grinding aids, materials for equipment maintenance, fuels, electricity, water consumption), the weighted average of each manufacturer"s unit flows was calculated. Except for the grinding aids, all other flows are not distinguished by cement type, as their consumption is reported for the whole cement plant, which usually produces more than one cement type. Water consumption was usually reported for the whole integrated cement plants (clinker + cement production operations). Based on literature and expert opinion, the total water volume was divided equally between the clinker and the cement production processes and then converted into unit flows. Raw materials and fuel inputs were considered to be dry. As water is mainly used for cooling and dust control, it was considered that all water evaporates, except for the "tap water" input, which was considered to be used as drinking water and whose output is modelled as an effluent. Fuel consumption was informed by manufacturers in terms of volume or mass. They were converted into energy using their lower heating values and modelled as a heat input, to simplify the dataset and allow the consideration of corresponding air emissions. Infrastructure input flow (cement factory) was extrapolated from "cement Portland/CH" dataset (accessed 08.10.2017). The amounts of the exchanges were calculated considering the weighted average of the sample. No conversion to the geometric mean of the lognormal distribution was done, for consistency reasons with other ecoinvent datasets.

exchanges.description: Cement’s bulk density ranges from 2,8 g/cm³ to 3,2 g/cm³.

exchanges.description: Measured value. Weighted average of values informed by manufacturers. 0,03 kg is mineral gypsum (primary raw material) and 0,02 kg is phosphogypsum (secondary raw material, by-product of phosphoric acid production); "gypsum, mineral" is used as proxy because phosphogypsum was not available in the ecoinvent database during dataset development.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Calculated as: ( water_unspecified_input+ water_well_input+ water_river_input+ (rainwater_input/1000))*cement. All water input except for tap water was considered to leave the system as evaporated water, as water is used for cooling and dust control.
